definitions.definition: (in the UK) a place where students go to study or to receive training after they have left school

examples.text: She wanted to **go to college** to become a nurse.
Not all the lecturers are in college at any one time.
The college runs a course for would-be arts administrators.
When I left school I went to secretarial college.

definitions.definition: (in the US) a university where students can study for a degree after they have left school
definitions.labels: (British English)(especially British English)(North American English)(North American English)(British English)(British English)(North American English)(North American English)(British English)(both British English, informal)(both especially North American English)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(North American English, informal)(both British English)(especially British English)(especially North American English)(British English)(North American English)(especially North American English, informal)(especially North American English, informal)(British English)(British English)(British English)(both North American English)

examples.text: She was the first in her family to **attend college**.
He's hoping to **go to college** next year.
I **graduated from college** with an English degree.
She's now in her first year of college.
He got interested in politics when he was in college.
She's away at college in California.
Their eldest son is just out of college.
The college graduated 50 students last year.

definitions.definition: a place where you can study for higher or more specialist qualifications after you finish high school
definitions.labels: (Canadian English)British EnglishNorth American EnglishNorth American EnglishBritish EnglishNorth American English

definitions.definition: one of the separate institutions that some British universities, such as Oxford and Cambridge, are divided into
(in the US) one of the main divisions of some large universities

examples.text: The history department is part of the College of Arts and Sciences.

definitions.definition: the teachers and/or students of a college

examples.text: The whole college was/were shocked to hear the news.

definitions.definition: a secondary school, especially one where you must pay
an organized group of professional people with special interests, duties or powers

examples.text: The College of Cardinals will choose the next Pope.
New guidelines have been released by the Royal College of Surgeons.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin collegium ‘partnership’, from collega ‘partner in office’, from col- ‘together with’ + legare ‘depute’.
